cards.Back: The foods habitually eaten by an individual or group.
The quantities, proportions, variety, or combination of different foods, drinks, and nutrients in diets, and the frequency with which they are habitually consumed.

High in fruits, vegetables, legumes, nuts, and grains; lower in salt, free sugars, and fats (especially saturated and trans fats); nutritionally adequate to maintain weight, supply energy, and reduce disease risk.

The study of foods and food substances that help animals (and plants) grow and stay healthy. Food provides energy (calories) and nutrients; nutrition science also examines behaviors and social factors related to food choices.
The consumption of specific foods and food components that comprise an individual's diet.
Values issued by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Academies that represent current knowledge on nutrient needs of healthy populations; individual needs may be higher or lower.
Intake that meets the needs of 97–98% of healthy individuals of a given age and sex.
A recommended intake based on observed or experimentally determined approximations when an RDA cannot be determined.
The highest daily intake unlikely to pose risk of adverse health effects; intake above the UL increases risk of adverse effects.
Standardized reference amounts used on labels, expressed as a percentage per serving toward a daily level; often similar to RDA or AI but not always.
Foods high in nutrients and relatively low in calories, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat or fat-free milk products, seafood, lean meats, eggs, peas, beans, and nuts.
Foods high in calories but low in essential nutrients; overconsumption is linked with overweight/obesity, type 2 diabetes, and some cancers; common in Western countries.

cards.Front: Name the three macronutrients and primary roles.
cards.Back: Carbohydrates: primary energy source. Protein: structural and functional roles (enzymes, carriers, hormones). Fat: structural membrane components, signaling, energy storage.
Simple carbohydrates are sugars; complex carbohydrates include starches and fiber.
A complex carbohydrate composed of glucose units; a major storage form of carbohydrate in plants.
Simple carbohydrates that provide energy; naturally present in fruits and milk and added to many processed foods.
Found only in plants; improves laxation and satiety, lowers coronary heart disease risk, and helps maintain normal glucose.
Forms viscous solutions that can slow gastric emptying and help lower LDL cholesterol; found in oats, barley, legumes, and many fruits.
Adds bulk and speeds transit through the gut; found in whole grains and many vegetables.
Approximately 14 g per 1,000 kcal; about 38 g/day for men and 25 g/day for women.
Complete proteins contain all essential amino acids in needed amounts; incomplete proteins lack one or more in needed proportions.
Soy protein contains all nine essential amino acids in adequate amounts.
Plants and microbes are the original source of essential amino acids.
Proteins are broken down by stomach acid and proteases into amino acids, which are absorbed and rebuilt into body proteins as needed.

cards.Front: Protein RDA and typical % of energy.
cards.Back: RDA is 0.8 g/kg/day. Example: ~55 g/day (~10–11% of 2000 kcal) for a 150 lb adult.
Varied whole plant foods easily meet protein requirements, especially with legumes, grains, and greens.
No; eating a variety of plant foods over time provides a complete amino acid profile.

cards.Front: Animal protein and acid load (bone concern).
cards.Back: High animal protein intake may contribute to diet-derived metabolic acidosis, with calcium mobilized from bone to buffer acid (area of active study).
Limit saturated fat; high intake is common in Western dietary patterns.
Present in foods such as olive oil, nuts, and avocados.
Include essential fatty acids; found in nuts, seeds, and certain plant oils.
Men: 17 g/day; Women: 12 g/day.
Men: 1.6 g/day; Women: 1.1 g/day.
Avoid partially hydrogenated oils; industrial trans fats have been largely removed from the food supply.
Cholesterol is found in animal-derived foods; dietary patterns emphasize plant-predominant choices.
They enable cellular metabolism and act as cofactors; deficiencies or excesses impair health.

cards.Front: Whole foods vs supplements for micronutrients.
cards.Back: Nutrient-dense whole foods are preferred; supplements do not consistently replicate benefits and can sometimes cause harm.
Few foods naturally contain vitamin D; many adults have low levels, so supplementation is often needed with low sun exposure.
Not reliably present in plants; fortified foods or supplements are recommended for plant-based eaters.
Heme iron is more readily absorbed; non‑heme iron absorption improves with vitamin C. Plant sources include legumes, greens, whole grains, nuts, and seeds.
Use fortified plant milks/yogurts, calcium‑set tofu, and low‑oxalate leafy greens; spinach and similar high‑oxalate greens have poor calcium bioavailability.
Plants provide little iodine unless soil is iodine‑rich; iodized salt or sea vegetables can supply iodine.
Neutralize free radicals and reduce oxidative stress. Examples include vitamin C, vitamin E, carotenoids, selenium, and zinc.
Commonly low intake; plant foods such as beans, potatoes, leafy greens, squash, bananas, and other fruits/vegetables provide potassium.
Legumes, nuts, seeds, and whole grains provide zinc; traditional preparation (soaking/sprouting) can improve availability.
Carbohydrates: 4 kcal/g · Protein: 4 kcal/g · Fat: 9 kcal/g.

cards.Front: Added sugars — common names you’ll see on labels
cards.Back: High-fructose corn syrup, corn syrup, cane sugar, fructose, sucrose, dextrose, lactose, honey, brown sugar, turbinado sugar (plus syrups and concentrates in ingredient lists).

cards.Front: Added sugars — major food categories contributing the most
cards.Back: Sugar-sweetened beverages (sodas, energy drinks), sweets/desserts, sweetened dairy, many packaged sauces/dressings/condiments, ready-to-eat cereals, and other prepared foods.

cards.Front: AHA guidance on saturated fat intake
cards.Back: Limit saturated fat intake; prioritize unsaturated fats (from plant-predominant sources) in place of saturated fat.

cards.Front: Common sources of saturated fat in the diet
cards.Back: Full-fat dairy (cheese, butter), red and processed meats, many baked goods, fried/fast foods, and some tropical oils.
Olive oil and other plant oils, nuts (e.g., almonds, hazelnuts), seeds, and avocados.
Nuts, seeds, and plant oils (provide essential fatty acids, including omega-6 linoleic acid and omega-3 alpha-linolenic acid).

cards.Front: Industrial trans fats — what to do?
cards.Back: Avoid partially hydrogenated oils; industrial trans fats have largely been removed from the food supply, but small amounts may persist in some packaged foods.
Cholesterol is present in animal-derived foods; a plant-predominant pattern naturally lowers dietary cholesterol intake.

cards.Front: Nuts — typical fat/protein profile per ounce
cards.Back: Nuts provide a mix of unsaturated fats and several grams of protein per ounce (exact values vary by nut; Brazil nuts are among the highest in fat per ounce).
Processed meats are consistently linked with higher cardiometabolic and cancer risk; counsel to minimize and replace with plant-predominant proteins.

cards.Front: Refined vs whole grains — practical distinction
cards.Back: Refined grains are milled/processed (removing bran and germ); whole grains retain bran, germ, and endosperm, offering fiber and micronutrients.

cards.Front: Added sugars on the Nutrition Facts label
cards.Back: “Includes X g Added Sugars” indicates sugars added during processing; use the % Daily Value to quickly gauge high/low contributions per serving.

cards.Front: % Daily Value (DV) — how to use it at a glance
cards.Back: The %DV shows how much a serving contributes to a daily level. ~5% DV is low; ~20% DV is high. Use it to limit nutrients like saturated fat and added sugar.

cards.Front: Ingredient lists — spotting added sugars quickly
cards.Back: Scan for multiple sugar terms (e.g., syrups, “-ose” sugars, honey). Ingredients are listed by weight, so early placement indicates larger amounts.

cards.Front: Dietary pattern emphasis for lipid improvement
cards.Back: Replace saturated fats with unsaturated fats and shift toward a plant-predominant pattern (legumes, whole grains, nuts, seeds, vegetables, fruits).
Prioritize water and unsweetened beverages; reduce SSBs (sodas, energy drinks, sweetened teas) to lower added sugar intake rapidly.
Avocados are rich in monounsaturated fats and fiber; useful as a replacement for saturated-fat sources in meals/snacks.

cards.Front: Eggs — key point for lipid counseling
cards.Back: Eggs contain cholesterol and fat; the overall pattern matters — emphasize plant-predominant choices and unsaturated fats.

cards.Front: Label literacy — two fast checks for patients
cards.Back: 1) %DV for saturated fat and added sugars (aim low)  2) Ingredient list for added sugars and refined grains.

cards.Front: Snack patterns — practical swaps to reduce saturated fat
cards.Back: Swap fried/packaged snacks for nuts/seeds, fruit, or vegetables with hummus; use olive oil–based dressings instead of creamy dressings.

cards.Front: Culinary guidance — where added sugar hides
cards.Back: Sauces and dressings (ketchup, BBQ, teriyaki), yogurts, cereals, granola bars, coffee drinks, and “health” snacks often carry substantial added sugars.
Higher fiber and unsaturated fats support LDL lowering; replacing SFA with MUFA/PUFA improves lipid profiles.

cards.Front: Refined-grain bakery items — what to flag on labels
cards.Back: Look for enriched wheat flour and added sugars listed early; prefer products labeled 100% whole-grain with minimal added sugar.

cards.Front: Processed meats — two reasons they’re problematic
cards.Back: High in sodium/saturated fat and associated with higher cardiometabolic/cancer risk; emphasize plant proteins instead.

cards.Front: Quick counseling script: cutting added sugar by half
cards.Back: Replace SSBs with water/unsweetened tea; swap sweetened yogurt/cereal for plain yogurt + fruit and plain oatmeal + nuts; check dressings and sauces.

cards.Front: Top food categories contributing sodium in the U.S. diet
cards.Back: Mixed dishes (burgers, sandwiches, tacos, rice/pasta dishes, pizza, meat/seafood dishes, soups) contribute ~50% of sodium intake.

cards.Front: Sodium counseling — Jeff Novick’s ‘rule of thumb’
cards.Back: If sodium per serving (mg) is ≤ kcal per serving, a 2300-kcal diet will stay around 2300 mg sodium/day.

cards.Front: Sodium intake thresholds to highlight for patients
cards.Back: General limit ≤2300 mg/day. Low-sodium intake is <1500 mg/day. Prepared/packaged foods can quickly exceed these thresholds.
Observational evidence does not show strong risk, but AHA advises dietary patterns inherently low in cholesterol (plant-predominant).

cards.Front: Top sources of cholesterol in U.S. diet
cards.Back: Meats (≈42%), eggs (25%), grain products with animal ingredients (17%), milk/dairy (11%).

cards.Front: FDA ruling on industrial trans fats
cards.Back: Declared unsafe; mandated removal from food supply. Associated with reduced cardiovascular events (ischemic heart disease).

cards.Front: Where do trans fats still occur?
cards.Back: Naturally in some meat and dairy; historically in partially hydrogenated plant oils (doughnuts, cookies, crackers, cakes, etc.).

cards.Front: Foods classified as Group 1 carcinogens (Nutrition Objective 1)
cards.Back: Alcoholic beverages and processed meats (per IARC). Both carry sufficient evidence of carcinogenicity in humans.

cards.Front: Vignette: Patient eats out daily, sodium 3500–4000 mg. What to recommend?
cards.Back: Counsel on checking labels, choosing lower-sodium entrées, asking for sauces/dressings on the side, and cooking at home to control sodium.

cards.Front: Vignette: Patient reads ‘0 g trans fat’ but sees partially hydrogenated oil in ingredients. How to respond?
cards.Back: Explain labeling loophole (<0.5 g/serving can be rounded to 0). Advise avoiding products listing partially hydrogenated oils.

cards.Front: Counseling: quick swaps to reduce sodium
cards.Back: Use herbs/spices, vinegar, or citrus instead of salt; choose unsalted nuts; opt for fresh/frozen vegetables over canned with added sodium.

cards.Front: Counseling: quick swaps to reduce added sugars
cards.Back: Replace sugar-sweetened beverages with water or unsweetened tea; choose plain yogurt + fruit over sweetened yogurt; oatmeal over sugary cereals.

cards.Front: Quick tip for interpreting %DV on labels
cards.Back: ≈5% DV is low, ≈20% DV is high. Use to compare brands and choose lower sugar, sodium, or saturated fat options.
